events.name: FOSSASIA
events.description:
FOSSASIA 2015 is an exciting Open Technology event for developers, students, and start ups using open source to build up their businesses. It is a unique opportunity to share the latest innovations in open source technologies and meet contributors and potential partners. FOSSASIA 2015 will take place for the first time in Singapore. It will be held at Plug-In@Blk71 from March 13-15.  Since the first FOSSASIA meetup in 2009 in Ho Chi Minh City, FOSSASIA has taken the lead to organize Free and Open Source Software conferences in Asia. Past FOSSASIA events have attracted over 1400 participants, speakers from 24 countries, and  more than 100 volunteers. More than half of all participants were women. 
Locations: 
1) Friday March 13, 9AM-5PM: The Opening event will take place on Friday March 13 at Biopolis, Matrix Auditorium, Level 2, 30 Biopolis Street (MRT Buona Vista).  
2) Saturday March 14/Sunday March 15, 9AM-5PM: 6 Tracks will take place at Launchpad Campus in Blk71 and Blk79 in 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, 139951 Singapore (MRT One North).
events.location: Biopolis, , Matrix Auditorium, Level 2, 30 Biopolis Street, Singapore null

events.name: FOSSASIA Open Technology Event - Opening at Biopolis
events.description: Join us at FOSSASIA 2015 Opening Event at Biopolis in Singapore this Friday. FIVE DAYS TO GO! Get your free tickets and invite your friends to do so now! FOSSASIA is an open technology conference, focused on the Asian continent, that offers developers, start-ups, hardware tinkerers and students an opportunity to meet, share ideas, and collaborate. Every year, tech communities from around Asia get together with fellow technology enthusiasts from around the world for days of learning and sharing. We have over 120 speakers. 90+ International speakers are flying in from around the world. Official Conference Registration: http://fossasia.eventbrite.com Program Friday March 13 9:00 AM Registration 9:30 AM Welcome by Hong Phuc Dang, Mario Behling, Harish Pillay 9:40 AM Bunnie Huang, Bunnie Studios, Novena 10:00 PM Mar Canet, Soft Digital Fabrication 10:20 AM Stefan Koehler, CronusConsult, The Power Of Free: How LiMux serves 15.000 10:40 AM Shout-Outs "Amazing OpenTech from Singapore and around the World" 10:50 AM Snack 11:05 AM Colin Charles, MariaDB , MariaDB - State of the Base 11:30 AM Gen Kanai, Mozilla, Paticipation in Mozilla and We achieve the Next Generation Open Web 11:55 AM Michael Christen, LokLak, Distributed Search and Open Index with Loklak 12:15 PM Lunch 1:15 PM Georg Greve, Kolab Systems AG, Collaborate with ease and confidence 1:40 PM Brian Proffitt, Red Hat Cutting Through The Container Hype 2:05 PM Feature Talks Roland Turner, Yahi: Crowd-Sourced Haze-Mapping, Internet of Things and Real-Time Open Data Jan Jongboom, Telenor Digital, Abusing mobile phones to make Internet of Things Mohit Kanwal, Pie Insecure Android Apps in Google Play Julien Lavergne, Lubuntu, Create your own distribution Remi Denis-Courmont, VideoLAN, VLC media player: news and future Italo Vignoli, The Document Foundation MIgrating to LibreOffice to reduce the desktop Total Cost of Ownership: methodology and case studies Emily Chen, GNOME, Open Data Platform based on CKAN Thomas Gorrisson, Temasys, Skylink.JS 3:05 PM Tea and Coffee 3:15 PM Lennart Poettering, Red Hat, systemd: where we come from, and where we want to go in 2015 3:35 PM Ryusuke Kajiyama, Oracle Corporation Japan, The State of the Dolphin 3:55 PM Kushal Das, Python Software Foundation Exciting days with Python 4:15 PM Bernd Erk, Icinga, Open Source Monitoring with Icinga 4:30 PM Rasmus Skjoldan, TYPO3 Designing a new content management system poses a beautiful problem: How do you design a tool you don’t know the exact future use of? events.name: TGIFHacks #31 - ACM ICPC
events.description: The ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest (ICPC) is the premiere global programming competition for college undergraduates. It is sponsored annually by IBM and Baylor University, and is now in its 39th year. ICPC challenges the problem solving abilities and programming skills of contestants on a wide range of interesting computer science problems. NTU organizes a number of ICPC teams each year. To help train students, we also hold weekly practice contests and discussions conducted by SCE faculty and PhD students. In October to December each year, we organize trips to regional contests. Top finishers then go on to compete in the world finals in May. NTU has been highly successful at ICPC, advancing to the world finals 10 out the last 12 years. This year our AAA team will compete in the finals in Morocco. Join us this Friday to learn more about ACM ICPC at NTU. See the problems and techniques used to solve those problems, meet participants and trainers, elaborate on complicated problems and finally, those who wish can try to compete in a short ICPC-like contest. The speakers this week are A/P Rui Fan, Senior Research Scientist Kevin Jones, and PhD student Lubos Krcal. Dr. Fan joined NTU in 2010 after getting his PhD from MIT. He is interested in algorithms and theoretical solutions to practical problems. Outline of the talk: About ACM ICPC Experience from previous competitions and finales Some advanced techniques students learn / use in ICPC Sample problem analysis (about 3 problems) ICPC-like competition for all attendees
events.location: TR+37

events.name: Meetup and Get Certified by the Linux Foundation at FOSSASIA
events.description: Join us for a Linux Foundation meetup and get certified as the Linux Engineer (LFCE) or the Linux System Administrator (LFCS) at FOSSASIA in Singapore for a special one-time discount of 100 USD off usual rates in cooperation with OlinData . We'll have a dedicated room on Saturday March 14, 2015 at Blk71 where you can sit down in all quietness and take the examination so you can walk away with one of the highest quality Linux Certification in the industry. Click here to sign up . A Linux Foundation Certified System Administrator (LFCS) has the skills to do basic to intermediate system administration from the command-line for systems running Linux. Linux Foundation Certified System Administrators are knowledgeable in the operational support of Linux systems and services. They are responsible for first line troubleshooting and analysis, and decide when to escalate issues to engineering teams. More information here: training.linuxfoundation.org/certification/lfcs Online Self-Paced Course : If you want to make sure you are prepared for the LFCS exam we have a great deal for you: By taking a special edition of the online self-paced course for the LFCS certification, you'll be well prepared for the LFCS certification and at the same time supporting FOSSASIA. Please go here to proceed. A Linux Foundation Certified Engineer (LFCE) possesses a wider range and greater depth of skills than the Linux Foundation Certified System Administrator (LFCS). Linux Foundation Certified Engineers are responsible for the design and implementation of system architecture. They provide an escalation path and serve as Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) for the next generation of system administration professionals. More information here: http://training.linuxfoundation.org/certification/lfcs Links FOSSASIA: http://fossasia.org Twitter: https://twitter.com/fossasia Certification: http://fossasia.org/linux
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, Ayer Rajah Crescent, #05-16, Singapore

events.name: PowerShell for Beginners
events.description: Just getting started with PowerShell? No problem! This is a half day event for complete beginners. Using recorded content from the Microsoft Virtual Academy and demonstrations from a PowerShell MVP and the User Group Leads, you'll finish the day much more confident with PowerShell than you were before. We have been hearing from the Community that there are not enough sessions for Beginners, also, some people are not confident about using PowerShell because they haven't had a good enough grounding in the fundamentals. We would like to address that. What are we doing at this Meet Up? This meet up is intended for those who want to get started with the basics of PowerShell. As PowerShell is not a new technology, there are many really awesome resources out there to get started. As such, we don't believe it is worth re-inventing the wheel. One of the best resources out there are the Microsoft Virtual Academy courses by the inventor of PowerShell Jeffrey Snover and MVP Jason Helmick which take you through as much as you need to get started. In this meet up we will be screening much of the content from Getting Started with PowerShell 3.0 Jump Start . This is an opportunity for those who have been interested in viewing this online but who haven't had time, or those who have watched it but are still a little unsure on some topics to go through it with us in an environment free of distractions. At the end of each module you'll be able to ask questions to clarify anything you're not sure of and we'll discuss, demo and bash keyboards until you feel you've mastered it! The day should follow along the lines of: • Welcome to the Session and set the scene - what is PowerShell, why so important and what are we doing here • Screen content from the MVA course, answer the quiz questions, do Q&A, any Demo's & further explanation • LUNCH! • Screen more videos • Wrap up and talk about what's next • Home Sweet Home All in all we will cover the Help System , the Pipeline , understanding Objects and Remoting . Having a sound grounding and solid understanding of these concepts will propel you forwards with your PowerShell Learning! Wait, why should I attend when I could watch this online?! Yes, you absolutely could watch this online in your own time, we believe the reasons to attend are: • To connect with like-minded people in the community that you don't connect with from behind your screen • Have the ability to ask questions when there is something you don't understand • Get a free lunch! • Have time and space free from the distractions of home or work to really concentrate, watch the material and learn it Is this a proper training event? Not really. User Groups should be seen as places to network and gather with like-minded folks and learn a little along the way. We don't make any commitment to turn you into experts and you only get out as much as you put in, but we commit to sharing our knowledge to help you improve and hope you will commit to sharing your knowledge with the group as well. So, what should I expect from this? Meet other PowerShell Enthusiasts. Be introduced to some great learning resources. To be given the time and distraction-free environment to learn from the Microsoft Virtual Academy. Lunch. How do I get the most from this? Bring your laptop - the best way to learn is by doing! Watch Video 1 from the Getting Started with PowerShell 3.0 Jump Start course. Be on time. Ask questions and participate Please remember this is aimed at Complete Beginners and all content will be at that level, though Intermediate folks may learn some tips and tricks along the way also.
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.name: Kendo UI: Building for User Experience with Sherman Chen
events.description: The workshop will be to share with other IT professionals and developers how they can leverage on Kendo UI's free core framework to create web & cross-platform applications that have better user experience for their target consumers or business clients. We will be looking into some of the core features and functionalities and some of the practical uses for Kendo UI in real world application scenarios. We will be sharing some look at the coding level applications, examples, and also answer Q & A at the end of the session. About This program is about Kendo UI's Core framework which is open sourced and readily available to developers who are keen to using it for various types of web & cross-platform application projects. Kendo UI is a product from Telerik. It has capabilities for integrating with other frameworks like Twitter bootstrap and AngularJS. Kendo UI is easy to learn and easy to apply as long as the developers have a foundational understanding in HTML5, CSS and jQuery. Sherman Chen Links Sherman: http://twitter.com/xdevap Company: http://xdev-ap.technology

events.name: Workshop: Migrating to LibreOffice to reduce the desktop Total Cost of Ownership
events.description: Join us for a free workshop and learn how to migrate organization to LibreOffice to reduce the desktop Total Cost of Ownership. Italo Vignoli, founder of LibreOffice, will introduce steps and case studies on Saturday at the Yellow Room in NUS Plug-In. The workshop starts at 10:55 AM. About LibreOffice is a free office suite, with a full feature set. As such, it is being used by large organizations to reduce the Total Cost of Ownership of end user desktops to a fraction of the cost associated with proprietary office suites. To ease the process, The Document Foundation has developed a methodology to assist organizations during the migration process, which has been successfully deployed in several public administrations. About Italo Vignoli Italo Vignoli is one of the founding members of The Document Foundation, the house of LibreOffice, and a long standing free software advocate. He is coordinating the certification project at TDF, and is a certified professional in the area of migrations and trainings. He is also a spokesperson for TDF, and one of the leaders of the marketing project. Links Italo Vignoli Twitter: https://twitter.com/italovignoli LibreOffice: http://libreoffice.com FOSSASIA: http://fossasia.org FOSSASIA Twitter: http://twitter.com/fossasia
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore

events.name: Fernvale: Shanzhai Tech Meets Open Hardware with Bunnie Huang and Sean Xobs
events.description: Join our Open Hardware Workshop with Bunnie Huang and Sean Xobs from Novena at FOSSASIA: "We will go over some concepts about our platform, based on the Mediatek MT6260. After some brief discussion about the legal and IP landscape, Sean will demonstrate how to hack phones and our own designs. Users with Linux laptops can follow along, we will bring a limited number of phones so people can play around with them. We do expect the phones back at the end of the workshop, we're not giving them way, just loaning them for the workshop duration." Please register for FOSSASIA at http://fossasia.eventbrite.com ABOUT Andrew "bunnie" Huang is an American hacker , who holds a Ph.D in electrical engineering from MIT and is the author of the freely available 2003 book Hacking the Xbox: An Introduction to Reverse Engineering . In 2013, bunnie announced that he, in collaboration with Sean 'xobs' Cross , was at work on a laptop called Novena . The laptop is expected to be the first of its kind. The hardware and software for the Novena are entirely open and only include components where the manufacturing companies do not require non-disclosure agreements to obtain the documentation necessary for design. [14] In addition to the normal laptop components, the Novena motherboard also includes an FPGA , dual Ethernet ports, a three-axis accelerometer, and easily extended hardware. [15] On May 7, 2014 the Novena's crowdfunding campaign reached its goal of $250,000 and went on to raise a total of $722,880 without taking subsequent pre-orders into account. Sean “xobs” Cross is an American living in Singapore. In the past hehas worked on release firmware for Chumby, including the Chumby One and Chumby 8 devices. He is currently building the firmware for Novena, along with the Senoko battery controller board. Most of his work is done with embedded ARM devices. He believes while there are a number of full-featured operating systems for ARM, none has more support than Linux. Venue Location FOSSASIA Workshop Track 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore 139951 Telephone: +65 6874 1292 Links Bunnie Huang: http://bunniestudios.com Sean Xobs: http://xoblo.gs FOSSASIA: http://fossasia.org Twitter: http://twitter.com/fossasia

events.name: Workshop: How to setup web scalable architecture with MySQL Fabric
events.description: At the free workshop at FOSSASIA Ricky Setyawan from Oracle teaches you how to setup a web scalable architecture with MySQL Fabric. MySQL fabric is a tool that was launched as part of MySQL Utilities 1.4. Fabric is written in Python and includes a special library that implements all the functionalities provided. Join us in the Python track at FOSSASIA in Blk71 at Silicon Straits. About MySQL Fabric MySQL Fabric seeks to make horizontal scale-out through sharding more accessible to users with growing data management requirements. This integrated framework supports management of large farms of MySQL servers, and includes support for sharding and high-availability. In this session, we will share how to setup a scalable web architecture with fabric. About Ricky Ricky Setyawan has been in the IT industry for 16 years with the good last 14 years working RDBMS specialist. He is currently MySQL Principal Sales Consultant for Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei and Pakistan. Prior to joining Oracle, he was workting at Stratus Technologies IT outsourcing arm doing database design, consulting and management on Oracle and DB2 on RedHat Linux on the ftServer - continuous availability server. He has been working on a number of RDBMS throughout his career such as Oracle, DB2, SQL Server, and MySQL. Links MySQL http://www.mysql.com FOSSASIA http://fossasia.org Twitter http://twitter.com/fossasia Silicon Straits http://www.siliconstraits.com ;

events.name: Open Sourcing Repair with Veerappan Swaminathan from Sustainable Living Lab Sg
events.description: Open Sourcing Repair (25 min) - Our consumerist culture has us continually buying and throwing away stuff even though it might only need a simple fix. This throwaway consumerism culture is highly damaging to the environment yet is very common in "developed" countries. Products are often not made to be repaired and instructions to fix stuff are often non-existent or opaque. Repair Kopitiam - a project developed by Sustainable Living Lab, aims to tackle this by bringing together people through online and real-life interactions in repairing their broken appliances, furniture and fabrics. In this talk, I'll be sharing some ideas to open source the repair of stuff. About Veerappan Swaminathan Veerappan is a Singaporean Maker, who startes the Sustainable Living Lab. He loves to share ideas, work on Open Source and repair things. Links FOSSASIA: http://fossasia.org Twitter: https://twitter.com/sl2square Website: http://www.sl2square.org
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore

events.name: Workshop: Choosing the right license & business model to keep your company alive
events.description: Choosing a business model is what will ensure revenue for your company, revenue that is vital to long term survival. There are several ways to make money from what is essentially perceived as free products. We will have a look at the various business models based on different means to make your product available to your customers. Choosing the right license for your project, as well as for code you incorporate into your project can be the life, or death (by lawyer) of your company. We will look at the various categories of licenses available to pick from, how you select the best one for your project, and what the implications are. License and business model are intimately linked, and one can often influence the other. This talk will cover both in perspective one of the other. About Gilles Gravier Gilles is the Director of Product Management for the Quantum-Safe Network Encryption Solutions (including Quantum Key Distribution Servers) product lines, as well as for the Quantum Random Number Generators, at ID Quantique, a company that is the leader in high-performance multi-protocol network encryption, based on conventional and quantum technologies, and aiming at providing future-proof encryption for data requiring long term protection. Prior to that, Gilles was chief technology strategist for security and open source at Sun Microsystems, advising the largest accounts globally on their IT security strategy as well as their open source activities. He moved on to develop global market and business development strategies for open source and security in the public sector still at Sun and then Oracle. He has been active as a technology evangelist, in particular for these companies, around cryptography, DRM, open source and open standards. He has worked extensively with venture capitalists as a strategic adviser for their due diligence process on IT start-ups, and is member of the boards (advisory or directors) of 3 startups. He is CISSP #91529. He occasionally posts on his blog : Thinking Open Source as well as on ID Quantique's blog. Gilles is a passionate photographer and travels either with his Canon EOS 6D or his PowerShot G12. He also shares his interest in astronomy with the neighboring elementary school children. Links Blog http://thinkingopensource.blogspot.com/ Twitter https://twitter.com/gravax FOSSASIA http://fossasia.org FOSSASIA Twitter http://twitter.com/fossasia
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore

events.name: Build your own distro with Lubuntu's Julien Lavergne
events.description: How useful would it be to give your customers a ready configured OS, that suits their needs right away? Or just how cool would it be to create your own OS for fun? Julien Lavergne Lubuntu maintainer will show us how to create your own distro based on Lubuntu. Meet us at FOSSASIA in the NUS Plug-In@Blk71 Lounge on Sunday at 10.30 (March 15). events.name: Functional Programming with Haskell for the OO Programmer with Calvin Cheng
events.description: Haskell is an obscure language in comparison with other popular languages/frameworks like python/django, ruby/rails, javascript/nodejs etc; and is usually not considered in 'mainstream' start-up projects. I decided to take a look and found it an impressive language that I am comfortable using, for a new production app in my company. Our current app uses golang for the API backend. I would like to share my experiences (and pain :-p) learning the language and why I am happy with it as our API backend for a new app. This session is a compressed learn-and-hands-on session with code examples. Talk participants will be guided with hands-on coding so as to understand Haskell's type system (built-in types and user-defined types), type classes and the O-ever-so-complicated monads :-). About Calvin Cheng I am a polyglot programmer, designer and system administrator who is familiar with interface design from Sketch to JS/CSS, iOS app development, server deployment as well as backend software implementation with Python and golang. I love my work and I am currently enjoying my experiments with backend development using Haskell/Yesod. Links Twitter http://twitter.com/calvinchengx Website http://calvinx.com
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore

events.name: Secure E7y Nomadic Toolbox with Harish Pillay from the Internet Society Sg
events.description: Secure E7y Nomadic Toolbox is an emergency toolbox to set up a local Internet. The workshop is to get people together to learn how to go about building an network using only tools that you bring to the workshop. So, please bring along things like laptops, wifi access points, antennae, raspberry pis, solar panels, battery packs, radio transmitters and just about anything that you can think of. The workshop will be handson - with what you have - to build a functional Internet that is self contained. During the workshop, no access should be made to the event's wifi and also any cellular networks. It is an emergency (e7y) situation where there are no external networks and we need to create our own network amongst all of the participants. This exercise will be documented and the Internet Society Singapore Chapter will hold similar, but extended, workshops on "Secure E7y Nomadic Toolbox" About Harish Pillay Harish Pillay is the president of the Internet Society Singapore Chapter. He is a pioneer on the Internet having gotten on to the ARPAnet and UUCP networks in 1985. He is a ham and his callsign is 9V1HP. Links Internet Society Singapore: http://isoc.sg Twitter https://twitter.com/harishpillay Blog https://harishpillay.wordpress.com/
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #02-18, Singapore

events.description: A technical workshop for beginners that would like to build a RPM package from their own software or from software they like and use. It also covers the basics and gives useful hints to avoid common mistakes and adds recommendations about optimized build environments for reproducible results. Additionally there will be a live RPM packaging demonstration for a small software including the possibility for participants for a practical exercise by packaging another small software as RPM. The workshop will also include an overview of the GNOME community structure, collaboration practices, and ways to start contributing. After that, established GNOME contributors will help participants work their way through the newcomers tutorial which teaches the process and the tools for downloading the code for a GNOME module, testing the module locally, submitting a bug report, and providing a fix for a bug. https://wiki.gnome.org/Events/NewcomersWorkshop Depending on participants interest and time persists there is also the chance to learn about i18n in your code. About Praveen Kumar Praveen Kumar is a long-time Fedora volunteer and Open Source contributor living and working in Redhat. In his free time, he is maintaining various software packages at Fedora, a leading Linux distribution, and promoting the Fedora Project as an ambassador at conferences. He’s an official Fedora Packager and supports different teams and individuals where ever needed. He also organized workshops in different FOSS event. Wiki: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/User:Kumarpraveen . About Anish Patil Anish Patil is working as Software Engineer at Red Hat. "I have been contributing to GNOME,Fedora and other free software projects since last 4 years. Regular speaker at Open Source conferences such as GNOME.ASIA, Fudcons" Website http://anish-patil.blogspot.in | Twitter: http://twitter.com/anish_patil

events.name: API LAB - Smart Nation API coLAB
events.description:

events.name: Null Singapore - March Monthly meet
events.description:
About null 
 null is an open security community for ethical hackers, security professionals and security enthusiasts, born out of the need for:  1. Promoting advanced security research.  2. Spreading security awareness among the netizens.  3. A Centralized knowledge base for security related information. 
All our Null Singapore meets are Free and Open to all, just register and join us.    Agenda : 
 6:30 - 6:45 Networking with fellow hackers 6:45 - 7:00 Security News Bites by Suman Sourav 7:00 - 7:40 IoT and security challenges by Randen Rosete 7:45 - 8:40 Experiences, lessons learned and approaches to infrastructure security by Sriram Narayanan 
  
Brief overview of the talks 
  
Security News Bites: A quick 15 min run down of the current happenings in security industry and anything which has some impact on anything related to information security. e.g.,    IoT and Security challenges: 1. Introduction to IoT/M2M 2. Application of IoT 3. Challenges - security otherwise general 4. The future of IoT 
Experiences, lessons learned and approaches to infrastructure security: 
Sriram will share his experiences of one of the attacks that he had to deal with, of mistakes made and lessons learned, and his current approaches to infrastructure security. 
  
About Speakers: 
  
Randen Rosete :  I have been a software engineer for the past 12 years, working on both Enterprise/Proprietary and Open Source Technologies. Currently I'm more involve in developing API and mobile applications. I had been interested with security and applies it to how I'm developing my applications.  Sriram “Ram” Narayanan :  Sriram “Ram” Narayanan, works with ThoughtWorks and helps customers get their products to market earlier by improving Release Engineering and Infrastructure Automation. He is a regular speaker, sharing lessons learned and ideas for improvement. When not working with technology, he is off practicing music or swimming.   Suman Sourav : 
Suman is having 10 years of experience in application & cloud security engineering, operation for banking & financial institutions, consulting firms, cloud service providers. He is working with Autodesk since last 1 year as Senior Security analyst for Product Security team. He has in-depth knowledge of secure software development lifecycle & vulnerability management, currently he is engaged with different product teams to reduce the software security issues in their products in development lifecycle, also providing guidance in making appropriate changes in process and policies in accordance to adopt the security process in development lifecycle. 
  
- Null Singapore Team.

events.name: WWF Presents - Climate Change And You - Get The Facts talk
events.description:
People in Southeast Asia will be among the worst affected by climate change. Have all your climate change questions answered by as WWF climate change expert and global policy advisor, Mr Sandeep Chamling Rai. Find out how climate change will affect you and how it will affect your food security and water supply. Most importantly, find out what you can do to protect yourself and prevent climate change. 
  
About Mr Sandeep Chamling Rai 
  
With more than 12 years of experience working on climate change issues, Sandeep has been a participant in various United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change negotiation since 2003. 
  
He was also the expert reviewer of Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Fifth Assessment Report (AR5), Working Group II (Impacts, Adaptation, and Vulnerability) report in 2014. 
  
Sandeep holds Master of Science Degree in Environmental Management from Pokhara University, Nepal and National University of Singapore (NUS), Singapore. 
  
  
Please kindly let us know if you are unable to attend the event so that we can better plan our capacity for the event. 
Frequently Asked Questions Is there an age limit to participate in the talk? This talk is recommended for adults and children (Age 6 and above).  
 Will there be food and drinks during the event? Yes. Light snacks and refreshments will be served after the talk. 
 What are my transport/parking options getting to the event? As parking space is limited in the vicinity, we strongly encourage you to come via public transport. The nearest MRT station is Botanic Gardens. And instructions on how to get there can be found here. 
  
I can't make it for the event, how do I go about cancelling my tickets? Please kindly drop us a line via our "Contact the organiser" button or simply email us at member@wwf.sg. 
  
Where can I contact the organiser with any questions? To contact us, please drop us a line via our "Contact The Organiser" button found at the bottom right side of this page. Alternatively, you can email us at member@wwf.sg 
  
Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? To minimise our impact on the environment, please refrain from printing your tickets but instead flash them on your mobile devices during registration. 
  
Is my ticket transferrable? Yes. Tickets are transferrable. However, to avoid any miscommunication, please email us at member@wwf.sg with the updated contact details of the new attendee as soon as possible. 
 The name on the registration/ticket doesn't match the attendee. Is that okay? Yes. However, to avoid any miscommunication, please email us at member@wwf.sg with the updated contact details of the new attendee as soon as possible.   Can I update my registration information? Yes. Please drop us a line via our "Contact the Organiser" button on this page or email us at member@wwf.sg.

events.name: Hack Night - The Code Editors Edition
events.description:
Its time to level up on your Editor-Fu, people! 
Choose an editor... any editor, and do something insanely great on it. Practice that nasty (but oh so useful) keyboard combo you've been dying to learn. Share your tooling setup and workflow... and learn some new tricks from your peers. Pick up some ideas on how to improve your productivity and have fun doing it. Make it a date to get some code done quickly (and well)! 
What is your weapon of choice? 
The editors we hope to cover are both terminal-based and GUI-based text editors and IDEs. Vim, emacs, Sublime Text, Atom, Brackets, Light Table, IntelliJ, RubyMine, PyCharm, etc. Most contemporary editors are infinitely extensible and powerful. 
Are you a guru on Sublime Text? Show us why it rivals what people can do on vim and emacs... =] Let us know what makes your shortcuts superior to others. 
Why master your editor? 
Mastery of the shortcuts keys and productivity features in your editor can help you get from idea to code in the shortest possible time. The text editor is the one vital tool of our craft. Its the direct expression of our thoughts into functioning code. 
Come share with us on this journey to enlightenment - in the way of the code!

events.name: Seminar @ NUS CeLs : ibidi – cells in focus: How to combine cell culture and cell based assays with high end microscopy
events.description:
Abstract 
Long-term imaging of living cells is an increasingly important technique in cell biology. Only during live cell imaging, cellular dynamics such as cytoskeletal rearrangements, migration and chemotactic behavior of the cell can be properly investigated. Therefore, it is crucial to provide in vivo near environmental conditions by controlling the pH as well as humidity and temperature. Especially in cancer and stem cell biology it is fundamental to conduct experiments under more physiological, hence hypoxic conditions. Further, sample preparation including the right surface for cell attachment is an important step in live cell imaging. 
ibidi’s research is focused on the development of functional cell based assays such as migration, chemotaxis and angiogenesis. Scientific applications and results from these fields will be presented. 
Details 
25 Mar 2015 (Wed), 10.30am - 11.30am  National University of Singapore,   Center for Life Sciences, Level 1,   Seminar Room 2   
Refreshments will be served. 
Speaker 
Dr. Tina Freisinger  Application Specialist  ibidi 
Tina Freisinger studied Biology in Munich and Edinburgh and pursued a PhD with a focus on cell biology and imaging at the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry in Munich. After receiving her PhD in 2012, Tina stayed on in the same lab as a postdoc and worked on a drug discovery project in collaboration with Novartis. After a 6-month marketing and sales internship at AMGEN, Tina joined ibidi as a global application specialist in October 2013. 
Enquire 
Daniaal Marican 
Email: daniaal@sciencewerke.com 
Contact No: +65 9046 9895
events.location: Center for Life Sciences (CeLS), Level 1, Seminar Room 2, , National University of Singapore, 28 Medical Drive, Singapore City 117456

events.name: TP InfoTechDay 2015: Free Workshops on IT Security Essentials & Forensics & Primer for Social Media Analytics
events.description:
The details of the workshops are as below: 
Track 1 Workshop: IT Security Essentials & Forensics (Starts 3.30pm, 2 hrs) 
This workshop consist of 2 use cases that enhance the network capability within data center from security and data analytics perspective.  1) MapReduce Tracer: EOS MapReduce Tracer tracks and interacts with Hadoop workloads directly connected to Arista switches in a cluster ensuring faster rebalancing and recovery in case of a node failure or congested link. 2) Splunk monitoring: Arista Telemetry application indexes switch inventory, topology, interface counters and statistics, syslog and LANZ data. This data is then exported to the Splunk server via the Universal Forwarder. 
  
Trainer Profile: 
Mr Mark Lee Currently Mark is working as the Senior Systems Engineer at Arista Networks. Mark is very experience in the network field with many years of working experience to back him up.  He is very knowledgeable in the network technology especially in routing, switching, MPLS etc. Mark is also specialized in Brocade and Juniper Network. 
  
Track 2 Workshop: Primer for Social Media Analytics (Starts 12.30pm, 1 hr) 
Data visualization can reveal insights that aren’t always obvious from looking at the raw data, no matter how well organized it may be. For social network, data visualization takes the form of a “social graph,” and it can be a powerful tool to discover deeper meanings and applications behind the relationships and communities within a network. Participants in this workshop will have a hands-on experience in building a social graph of their facebook friends through an interactive visualization and exploration platform. Come and find out more about your very own social network to gain personal insights! 
  
Trainer Profile: 
Goh Kai Song is a lecturer at the School of Informatics & IT in Temasek Polytechnic.  Kai Song is a double Master’s degree holder, having graduated from the National University of Singapore with a Master’s Degree in Computing, as well as a Master’s Degree in Education from the University of Sheffield (UK). He had conducted workshops and seminars on business intelligence & analytics. Kai Song’s research interest is in the application of analytics in the area of education.   
  
Samantha Sow is a lecturer at the School of Informatics & IT in Temasek Polytechnic. Samantha graduated from the National University of Singapore with First Class Honours Degree in Engineering. Her specialisation is in Mathematics & Statistics, and she believes in sharing her knowledge and skills to nurture the future generation and work force.

events.description:

The showcase includes projects developed in collaboration with industry partners and various agencies and provides an opportunity for both students and industry guests to discuss employment opportunities.  This year, as part of our 25th anniversary celebration, we have also invited speakers from SCS, CISCO, Singtel and NCS to share on the latest trends for Big Data & Smart Solutions. Topic 
  


Analytics in the Cognitive Era 




First Speaker Profile 
 
  
  


James Kocis is the Analytics Leader for IBM’s Globally Integrated Capability.  James leads Business Analytics & Strategy delivery resources that are based in eight centres globally: India, China, Philippines, Romania, Egypt, Brazil, Mexico, and Argentina.  James also is responsible for an Analytics Solutioning team that architects innovative solutions for clients globally. These solutions leverage Cloud, Analytics, Mobile, Social, and Security capabilities based on assets from IBM Research, Software, Hardware, and Services divisions.  
James has over 20 years of industry and consulting experience. Prior to his current role, James was the worldwide Strategy and Operations leader for IBM’ Business Analytics team, the large deal leader for IBM Japan’s Analytics team, and held a variety of sales, project management, and delivery roles.   
James is currently on the executive steering committee for the Centre for Business Analytics at the National University of Singapore (NUS). James is from New York City but he and his family have lived in Singapore for two years. 
 



Synopsis 
  


We are entering a new era of computing. From tabulating systems to programmable computers, now cognitive computing represents a huge leap forward. This new era brings with it fundamental differences in how systems are built and interact with humans.  We have recently seen Analytics move to the forefront of the CxO agenda.  With the advent of Cognitive Computing, we now have the opportunity to take Analytics to the next level and achieve outcomes previously unimaginable. 
  




  




Topic 


Handling Big Data with Google Cloud Platform 
  




Second Speaker Profile 
 


Krishnan is a Google Developer Expert (GDE) in Google Cloud Platform (GCP). He is the first GDE in GCP from SEA and currently the only one in GCP as well. Krishnan is also a co-founder of Google Developer Group, Singapore and founded the same in 2009. He has helped to organise a total of 50 developer-focused events as part of this community activity as of Dec 2014. 
Krishnan is currently with Institute for Infocomm Research, Singapore. He has 16+ years of industry experience in Cloud Computing, High Performance Computing, Computer Security, Data Analytics, and Embedded Systems. Earlier, Krishnan graduated with PhD in Computer Engineering (High Performance Computing) from National University of Singapore, Singapore and before that with MS by Research in Computer Science (Systems security) from NUS as well. 
 



Synopsis 


In this talk, the speaker will present the technical aspects of big data technologies and products that are part of the Google Cloud Platform. In addition, the talk will focus on few other technologies from Google Cloud Platform that are required for pre- and post-processing of big data.  




  




Topic 


Defining the Internet of Everything 
  




Third Speaker Profile 
 


Jared Danaraj, Director, Business Development, Industry Solutions and Ecosystems, APJC, Cisco Systems 
Jared leads Cisco's strategic alliances in vertical industries and Internet of Everything (IoE) industry partnerships in Asia Pacific. His team focuses on developing IoE ecosystems, go-to market strategies and industry solutions with partners with the aim of solving customer business challenges via intelligent networks. 
Jared joined Cisco Singapore in 2007, and has a track record of delivering positive business outcomes with customers, regional developers, ICT solutions providers and key industry partners in Asia-Pacific in large, complex projects covering Smart Cities, Transportation and Manufacturing. Prior to joining Cisco, Jared was leading business development in the area of communication engineering in Middle East for NCS (part of the Singtel Group). 
Jared holds various professional certifications in Project Management, Enterprise Architecture and Design Thinking. Jared completed his post-graduate studies at the National University of Singapore and was a recipient of the National Science adn Technology Board Scholarship.  He's also a published scientific author and holds an MBA with the Chicago Booth School of Business. 
  




Synopsis 


The Internet of Everything is here. More people, processes, data and things are connecting. It's creating more compelling experiences, new markets and greater efficiency than ever before. IT leaders around the world must now embrace this new model, making themselves more strategic and more nimble, and a source of innovation and transformation across their organization. In this session we’ll take a look at an industry view of the Internet of Everything and the opportunity that it presents all of us. 
  




  



Topic
Smart Policing: Developing "Information for Action" Through Big Data Analytics



Fourth Speaker Profile 
 


Dr Clifton Phua,Associate Director, Analytics | Smart and Safe City Centre of Excellence. Clifton is at NCS Group, working on Big Data analytics for customers. In his free time, he volunteers professional services to events, conferences, and journals (related to data mining/analytics, security and health informatics). Was also part of teams which won some analytics competitions. 
His specialization was Big Data analytics in public security (attack and disaster preparation/recovery/response; cyber security; internal security; and predictive policing) and fraud (government, banking, and insurance). 
He is an associate editor for the IEEE Transactions on Big Data (IEEE TBD) and Big Data Journal, and editorial board member of International Journal of Cyber Warfare and Terrorism. In addition, he is a program committee member of IEEE International Conference on Big Data, Joint Intelligence and Security Informatics Conference, and International Symposium on Foundations of Open Source Intelligence and Security Informatics. 
His teams have won challenges such as GE Flight Quest Phase 1 Competition 2013 and Fraud Detection in Mobile Advertising Competition 2012. He has published more than 30 technical papers on various industry applications of data analytics, such as fraud detection and activity recognition. 
Clifton’s PhD (on identity crime detection) and bachelor's (first class honors) degrees are from Clayton School of Information Technology, Monash University, Australia. 
  



Synopsis

Smart policing is the use of analytical techniques in law enforcement to address crime and policing problems more effectively. The consistent strategic problem faced by law enforcement agencies globally is how to achieve the best results with limited resources.  This includes maintaining public order, reducing crime, or maintaining the current status quo with reduced resources. In order to solve these issues, we must discover the actionable predictors (such as time and weather) of different types of crime, specific to each location or place type (such as a neighborhood or nightclub), in order that resources are used to best effect. This talk examines preliminary results using the UK Police Crimes and Outcomes dataset from December 2010 to June 2014, which has a relatively large volume: more than 19 million crime and anti-social behavior incidents from 43 police forces ( please see http://data.police.uk/ ). 
Finally, this talk explains how smart policing is applicable to campus security. 
  




  
 FAQs 
Where can I contact the organiser with any questions? 
Please feel free to email ryanlbk@tp.edu.sg if you have any questions.

events.name: Silicon chips with quantum inside?
events.description:
Silicon Chips with Quantum Insides? 
For over half a century, silicon has been the material platform for the information processing revolution that has transformed our society. From Silicon Valley to Silicon Straits, this humble material has become synonymous with high-tech enterprise driven by the ever increasing computation power and shrinking size of CMOS processors. However, transistors cannot simply keep getting smaller (the characteristic size of CMOS transistors is now only 60 atoms wide). At these scales, the bizarre laws of quantum mechanics come into play: electrons can be in two places at once (called ‘superposition), and can ‘tunnel’ through barriers. Controlling electrons at these scales becomes a bit like herding (Schrödinger) cats, making it impossible to build basic computing components. Chip designers today have been using all their ingenuity to fend off this ‘quantum limit’ for a few more years with novel designs, but reaching the limit is inevitable. Instead of trying to work around these troublesome quantum effects, it is possible to build an entirely new type of computer whose operation fundamentally relies on quantum features such as superposition. There are a wide range of different technologies being explored to build such a ‘quantum computer’, including arrays of trapped ions addressed by lasers, and circuits of superconducting aluminium kept a few thousands of a degree above absolute zero. Recent results from laboratories around the world suggest that silicon could in fact provide a platform for such quantum processors - this include superposition states that last for 3 hours, or being able to measure individual dopant atoms in silicon nano-devices. We still have a little way to go before silicon can be considered to be on an equal footing with other quantum computing designs, but this isn’t the first time silicon has played catch-up. After all, lead sulfide and germanium were used to make transistors before high-purity silicon and CMOS technology came along. So far, we have every reason to think that silicon will survive the next big computational leap, from the classical to the quantum age. 
  
John Morton studies the coherent control of electron and nuclear spins in solid state materials and devices, with a focus on quantum technologies. Quantum technologies are ones which exploit quantum superposition and entanglement to achieve major advances over current technologies in areas including communication, sensing and information processing. 
  
  
  
  
  
  
This event is organised by the Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore in partnership with the Science Centre Singapore.

events.name: MasterCard hackathon, Masters of Code
events.description: Hey Creators! MasterCard hackathon is taking place in Singapore on March 28-29. Use the code HackAngel for free tickets. http://bit.ly/mocsg The CONCEPT How is a truly gifted Coder (as in programmers, designers and developers) distinguished today? For thousands of years, master artisans were honored with an insignia in recognition of their talent. A distinct object such as a pin or hat established their dominance in a field. “Coders”, as we define them here, have become the world’s newest artisans. Just as master builders were essential for the creation of a business 400 years ago, Coders are needed for everything from website creation to server maintenance and developing new in-house platforms. Yet there is no identifying seal showcasing the quality of Coders, their rank amongst peers or even their trials and accomplishments. Enter the MasterCard Masters of Code Competition. Through this intense series of hackathons we have one goal: to traverse the globe and engage the very best Coders. Each regional hackathon will have developers, designers and entrepreneurs using the MasterCard APIs to create masterful prototypes that demonstrate artful coding and design skills, while articulating clear business cases. The competition will be intense and the tension high, but we are looking to create a different experience for our participants. Each event will be held in one of the most thriving tech communities worldwide – and at the best venues there. Winners from each region will be flown out for the Grand Finale Masters of Code Hackathon in Silicon Valley to experience a MasterCard Priceless Experience – Northern California. The final itself will be just like the regionals with up to ten teams from the region events and one MasterCard elite team of Coders. The winning team will be recognized as the first Masters of Code Champions and given their Masters of Code Jackets, $100,000 and many other perks. Only the global winning team will be given this honor and privilege. THE COMPETITION Regional Level: Each region has a specific Challenge, Featured API and Secret API that attendees can go after. While you don't have to use all three in your hack, bonus points will be awarded to those that do. The Singapore Challenge: Using Commerce/Payments to Empower Women The Singapore Featured API: Simplify Commerce The Singapore Secret API: Shh, you'll have to wait for the event to find that out... PRIZES Grand Prize* The MasterCard Masters of Code Champions will be crowned and will receive $100,000 to develop their innovation, in addition to the following prizes*: Two weeks on-site at the MasterCard Start Path™ accelerator location in Dublin, Ireland, or an alternate remote program Six months of mentoring from a member of the MasterCard Open API executive team and the Start Path program team Free payment processing for up to $250,000 in transactions for the first 12 months using Simplify Commerce**.. *Prizes may be modified to accommodate regional availability and regulations of the winning team location **Legal Disclaimer: To qualify for this promotion, a Masters of Code team must apply to become and be approved as a Simplify Commerce merchant and actively transact via Simplify Commerce Gateway. “Actively transact means conducting a sales transaction that results in Simplify Commerce making a deposit to the checking account you have linked to your Simplify Commerce merchant account. If you qualify, Simplify Commerce will rebate the 2.85% + 30¢ per transaction processing fee for your first $250,000 in sales that occurs within 12 months after the company becomes a Simplify Commerce merchant. Should a transaction be refunded, it will not be eligible for a rebate. After the company reaches $250,000 in sales, processing fees will remain 2.85% + 30¢ per transaction (or the standard rate at that time). Regional Winner Singapore Masters of Code Title: The first of it's kind. Place in the Grand Finale in Silicon Valley in December: The winning team will be flown to Silicon Valley to compete in the Grand Finale Masters of Code hackathon (up to 5 members) MasterCard Priceless® Experience in Napa Valley and San Francisco – while at the Grand Finale in December Regional Runner-Up Each regional runner-up team member will receive a $500 USD MasterCard gift card. RULES AND JUDGING CRITERIA Rules: Teams of up to 5 humans are allowed. You can also add 1 cyborg, Furby, drone, or Sphero. All team members must have completed the participation agreement to compete. We all start coding at the same time. This is done to keep things fair. Please don't come in and build on top of previous projects if you want to win. You must demo your hack in order to present. No slide-decks or power-points will be allowed. 2 minute presentation 1 minute Q&A from Judges. Teams have full ownership of everything they build at our events and are free to do with it as they wish. Each hackathon has its individual hackathon.io page, which projects should be submitted on. Submission time is 1pm Sunday. Winning teams will be subject to a code-review at some point following the event or immediately before winning. Judging Criteria: All judging will be done on Hackathon.io Scores are out of 25 points for the following criteria: Impact Design Creativity Simplicity Usage of MasterCard's APIs SCHEDULE Saturday, March 28th Sunday, March 29th 09:00 - Doors open to Attendees 08:00 - Breakfast 09:30 - Breakfast of Champions 12:00 - Lunch 10:00 - Opening Ceremony and API Talks 13:00 - Hackathon Ends/Submission due on hackathon.io 10:30 - Team & Idea Pitches 14:00 - Demos Begin - Demos only, No slide decks 12:00 - Lunch (if your demo doesn't work, take us through the code- 13:00 - CODING BEGINS and Breakout Sessions what you did and where you got stuck. It's about 18:00 - Dinner is Served showing what you've learned and not about pitching an idea). 00:00 - Midnight Snack 17:00 - Winners are announced/Prizathon! CODE THROUGH THE NIGHT! And that's a wrap!

events.name: ISS Seminar: Digital Analytics – The Game Changer for the Hospitality Industry
events.description:
Hospitality managers need to enhance the way they make decisions by using actionable insights through the use of digital analytics.  
Online reservations, reviews and ratings in the hospitality industry, have led to the managers owning numerous data. 
But what does the manager do with this data? In order to manage the business well, the manager needs to use the data to answer the many questions that management is interested in. And also to help them make better decisions to increase productivity and sales, and to improve their customers' experience. 
For example, management may be interested in, “Who is likely to be a guest at the hotel and why?”, or “What is the average daily rate per room?”, or “What is the vacancy rate of the hotel?” 
There are many analytical techniques that can answer these business questions. Techniques in “Predictive Analytics”, “Channel Distribution Optimisation”, “Customer Analytics”, “Recommendation Systems”, and others. 
We have invited hospitality experts to tell us how digital analytics can help managers: 

Determine who are their guests and profile them
Understand why guests choose their hotel/airline/restaurant/services
Determine guest satisfaction with their services
Which guests rate their services highly and how to improve guest satisfaction
To design  more effective digital strategy campaigns
Perform comparative analysis among hotels 
Better understand the competitive landscape.

 The hospitality industry is extremely competitive. Managers need to be more proactive in their decision making or their competitors will soon beat them at their own game and become the new leaders in the industry. 
The use of digital analytics is growing in the hospitality industry. Come and learn from hospitality experts, how to make good use of your data when making decisions.  
 Who should attend 
Professionals in the hospitality industry who are interested to find out how their organisations can gain competitive advantage over their competitors by making data-driven decisions.   
 For more information, visit https://www.iss.nus.edu.sg/Events/ISSSeminars/DigitalAnalyticsTheGameChangerfortheHospi.aspx

events.name: How to measure user experience and reduce abandonment by more than 30%
events.description: Whether you are well established e-Commerce brand such as Zalora, Agoda or a small business with a web shop, it’s never too late to gain more insights into your customers’ end user experience to make better decisions on where next to spend engineering and marketing money. With the establishment of mobile web and native mobile apps, your website isn't the only customer touch point anymore and it is critical to deliver the same user experience across all the channels (Mobile App/Mobile Web/Web). In order to do that you need to find a way to monitor and measure user experience across your delivery channels to allow both business and engineers to make the right decisions on where to invest time and money to improve user experience. Join us, as Andreas Grabner, Technology Strategist at Dynatrace, shares best practices from different global companies and learn: - which metrics you really need to monitor across your channels -how to make data-driven decisions based on these metrics -changing your deployment model of applications and new features to become metric driven and not just demand driven

events.name: Hebocon Singapore (Robotics competition for the technically ungifted)
events.description: The search for Singapore's worst robot will take place some time this year (most likely in July 2015). Known as Japan’s "worst robot competition”, the purpose of the HEBOCON event is to find out which crappy robot is the ultimate failure of them all through a sumo-styled wrestling battle. Preparations are being made to bring this quirky robotic competition to Singapore. We are looking for venue hosts, sponsors, contributors and supporters for this inaugural event. More details about guidelines and rules of competition will be announced in March 2015. Meanwhile stay cute and unskillful! If you're interested to participate, please indicate your attendance here. Thank you. *the date indicated below is a tentative one. the confirmed schedule will be release in Mar 2015 For more information about HEBOCON, check out the official page at https://www.facebook.com/Hebocon.Official
events.location: TBD
